title: The Hidden Beauty of Wintry, Urban Landscapes
text:
When thinking of the concept of nature, there is often a close association with undeveloped, pristine landscapes like beaches and mountains, usually during summer months, when landscapes are full of life and the weather is nice. However, these spaces are often not easily accessible. Millions of people across the northern hemisphere live in heavily developed urban spaces, with the cold months of winter making up a significant portion of the year. This disconnect between societal conceptions of nature and the natural spaces that are most accessible brings consequences, particularly during less desirable seasons like winter, including a lack of human-nature interaction in urban ecosystems and large gaps in our understanding of their ecology. However, urban spaces and every season play an important role in ecological function and provide numerous benefits for human society. Through the following reflections, I aim to highlight the underappreciated value of wintertime urban landscapes, by showcasing their biodiversity and the ecosystem services they provide.
When you picture a beautiful landscape, what do you imagine? A mountain illuminated by the rising sun? A forest of towering trees? Waves crashing onto a rocky shoreline? Maybe you picture your favorite national park or a local landscape particularly memorable to you?
For me, it’s usually a mountain, sometimes in the Rockies, other times in the Sierras. I picture these mountains as wild, untouched places, free from development, even if they aren’t in reality. I picture something a little like this:
I picture this because these are the places I love. Summertime camping and hiking trips into the mountains are a significant part of who I am and represent times that I am filled with happiness. Here’s the irony: I spend relatively little time in these places. I don’t live in the mountains and the summer months vanish in the blink of an eye.
I live in the city and winter makes up almost half the year.
Sometimes, I find it difficult to see the beauty in the places I spend most of my time. I still struggle with it, truthfully. Perhaps you do too.
I want to share some scenes from where I currently find myself as I write these words: the city of Fort Collins in northern Colorado on a stormy winter’s night. Winter here in the city is a quiet time of year. The plants are colored in varied hues of browns and grays. Snow occasionally covers the seemingly dead grass and the cold ground.
So I want to ask, what do you think when you see this image, taken here in Fort Collins at a local park? How would you describe it? How does it make you feel?
And what of this image, taken at a busy intersection surrounded by apartments here in Fort Collins?
I doubt these represent the images you visualized earlier as beautiful landscapes. You might describe the first image as boring, gray, dead, or unappealing. You might have described the second image as artificial, developed or unnatural. Regardless of the exact words that you used to describe these landscapes, I’m fairly confident there was little overlap between those adjectives and the ones you would use to describe your favorite natural area.
This brings us to the crux of the issue. Throughout much of the US and even much of the northern hemisphere, many people spend a significant portion of their time in places that look like these images: city streets lined with apartments and urban parks that for half the year look brown and gray. Thus, we spend most of our time in places that feel dreary and monotonous, rather than inspiring. I want to show you that this isn’t always the case. Over the course of this essay, I’m going to share a few moments that have led me to reflect on this disconnect and see the ecological value and beauty of our urban landscapes.
I spend a lot of time biking year round here in Fort Collins, regardless of the weather. During the summer, these bike rides are often enjoyable. I regularly hear finches and warblers singing and the weather is pleasant. The winter is often the opposite. During this time of the year, the focus is less on enjoying my rides through town and more on getting from point A to point B. It’s cold and often windy and I just want to get to my destination and get inside.
Thus, in winter I spend a lot less time enjoying the journey. But, every once in a while, among the grays of bare trees and concrete, a flurry of activity and noise makes me stop and marvel for just a few moments. Robin and waxwing flocks, colorful and wonderfully noisy as they feast upon the few trees with fruits still hanging from their branches, always make me stop.
There’s just something about the contrast of the vibrant, active flocks against gray skies and dead lawns that makes them stand out. It’s incredible to see these beautiful birds in neighborhoods and otherwise quiet parks. Often, I see them feasting on the bright red fruits of crabapple trees planted along the streets or eating the berry-like cones of juniper trees found throughout Fort Collins’ neighborhoods.
The presence of these fruit-bearing trees act as miniature oases, whether they are next to a busy highway or in a park. They provide vital food sources during the coldest parts of the year when the abundance of insects and other food sources is low.1 Without these planted fruit-bearing trees and shrubs, both native and introduced,2 the winter survivorship of robins, waxwings, and other frugivorous birds and mammals might be much lower.
Next time you pass a leafless tree with bright red berries, pause for a moment and notice if anything is feeding on those vibrant, fruity gems.
Let me set a different scene. It’s a cold January morning, just as the sun is rising and the sky begins to lighten. Temperatures rest below freezing, the sky is a dull gray and a few inches of fresh snow lie on the ground. It’s by no means the ideal time to be outside, but here I am regardless, having just arrived at a small local park sandwiched between two neighborhoods.
Cottonwood trees stand tall, their bare branches reaching to the sky, and brown cattails cluster around the small stream that runs through the park. Even this stream is not natural, shaped and sculpted by humans to direct storm and flood waters in a direction most beneficial to us. However, this small, heavily managed wetland and riparian woodland offers an invaluable refuge to numerous species of wildlife some of which I spy on this day.
In the past, I remember being thrilled to see a red fox scurry across the path, pausing for only a moment before disappearing into brown grass the same color as its fur. Other times, I encountered small herds of mule deer that had come down from the foothills and mountains to take advantage of the abundant food and milder climate. I have seen great horned owls here many times, hunting over the marsh and preening in the trees. Today, these memories propel me forward through the cold as I wonder what I will find hidden in this marsh.
After some wandering I spotted something lurking in the snow-covered reeds of this urban park only 20 feet from a suburban home. At first, I see just a bit of movement in the cattails, then a smudge of brown, and then out pops a gray face and a long, orange bill. A Virginia Rail, a secretive creature rarely seen in the open. It dips its curved beak into the frigid water, probing for the small aquatic plants, the only green present here in the winter. It continues feeding for a moment, until a hawk swoops down and it scurries off into the reeds to hide.
It’s often easy to dismiss urban spaces as ecological voids. This tiny natural area, however, tells a different story. It provides valuable habitat for even the most secretive and shy creatures. Rails, owls and foxes thrive in these small patches of habitat. Often, riparian urban forests much like this one serve to negate some of the impacts urban spaces have on ecosystem functions, improving species richness and abundance in these tiny oases of heavily managed wilderness..3
During the wintertime, one of the places I visit more than any other is the local City Park. It has expansive grassy lawns, many scattered trees and a few sports fields. In the summer, this park becomes a community gathering space, hosting live music, youth soccer games, and providing ample space to picnic. In the winter, it’s a lot quieter. People come to walk or run through the park, but few people stop to just relax and enjoy the space, especially during the coldest months.
For me, the real draw to this park in the winter is the small lake. This lake has one special feature only possible due to its highly artificial nature: it’s aerated. At a few select locations, air bubbles out of underwater pipes and keeps the water constantly circulating. This prevents parts of the lake from freezing over, even when temperatures drop below freezing for weeks on end.
On these small patches of open water, some of the only a few such areas in the region during the winter, hundreds, if not thousands, of geese and ducks congregate. It is a spectacle to behold. Tightly packed geese and dozens of vibrant and brightly colored mallards and shovelers stand out against the bright white of ice and snow as they swim through the dark, cold water.
This park is more than just a resting place for these abundant waterfowl, it provides food for multiple species. Goldeneyes dive deep below the water, feasting on the crustaceans that lurk in the depths. Mallards feed on the water’s surface and on food given to them by park visitors, even beginning to court one another as the winter draws to a close. Geese forage on the grassy lawns around the pond. This abundance of waterfowl draws those that prey on them, like the magnificent Bald Eagle. In the right conditions, especially when extremely frigid temperatures fall on northern Colorado, freezing nearly all of the reservoirs, it is possible to find half a dozen eagles here at this small pond, feasting on geese and ducks.
This urban pond, despite its blatantly artificial appearance and its location in the middle of a busy city, nonetheless hosts an incredible diversity of life in the winter, especially in terms of waterfowl and other birds. This is true not just at this small city park, but others elsewhere in the country. Take Forest Park in the heart of St. Louis, Missouri, for instance. It’s a large urban park with a few artificial lakes, a golf course and some sports fields. This urban park, surrounded by businesses and homes, is known to host the majority of all waterfowl species found in the surrounding regions, providing valuable habitat in the middle of a sprawling city.4 These urban lakes provide valuable feeding and resting grounds for many species during a time of year when bodies of water are often frozen and inaccessible.
I chose to share these stories and these places because they highlight some of the unique and important ways wildlife interact with urban settings, and they are some moments that resonated strongly with me personally. However, these stories are only some of the ways that nature and urban places coexist. Leaf litter from neighborhood trees is used by many insect species to survive the winter.5 Small mammals, such as squirrels, run amok throughout residential areas and urban parks, feasting on whatever they can find. Bird feeders can provide stable food sources for numerous species, alleviating some of the difficulties of foraging in the winter.6 All of these and so much more are examples of how urban areas and biodiversity can not just exist together but even benefit one another.
However, urban landscapes not only provide value to ecosystems, but to human society as well. Interacting with and spending time in nature conveys numerous health benefits to people, from improving mental well-being7 to increasing attention span in children.8 Yet, every winter, I notice an unsurprising pattern; I encounter fewer people outside, especially when temperatures dip below freezing. Nowhere have I seen this more noticeably than at a local park I frequent. Here, there is an owl roost well known among members of the community. On a warm day, it’s not uncommon to see lots of people taking a moment away from their walk to admire these owls, sometimes drawn by the presence of birdwatchers or photographers On a cooler day, however, there are often far fewer people walking along the trail and usually no one checking out the owl.
This is not just a phenomenon here at this park and at this owl roost. In other parks elsewhere in the world, people tend to interact less with nature during the wintertime, with potential consequences for their health and well-being.9 Beyond that, fewer people interacting with nature means that less data is contributed to large citizen science projects, like iNaturalist10 or eBird,11 during the wintertime. Far less scientific research across numerous ecological disciplines is conducted during the winter, leaving broad gaps in our collective knowledge. This, especially in urban environments, poses a risk.12 This, especially in urban environments, poses a risk.
Urban environments and the species they both coexist with and displace are already at great risk. Wintertime is already a time of hardship for many species, as food is scarce and freezing temperatures come frequently. The dearth of valuable data and research during this time of year translates to a lack of critical knowledge necessary for informed decisions about development, management, and conservation. This, in turn, can exacerbate issues in already stressed urban environments.
Urban environments often have far less biodiversity than nearby rural areas or undeveloped land. For instance, your neighborhood probably hosts only a few common species of birds, mammals and insects, and you may not notice them as often. Yet, when you go to a natural area, park or protected area, chances are you notice a lot more around you. This phenomenon has been recorded throughout the world, across different seasons, and across the taxonomic tree.13
Despite lower biodiversity, urban spaces provide us with many services that often go unnoticed.14 Urban forests, such as natural areas or arboretums provide recreational opportunities and help regulate the nearby climate, minimizing the impacts of urban heat islands. Parks and suburban lawns aid stormwater drainage and clean pollutants from the air. Even seemingly insignificant street trees help reduce urban noise and provide habitat for birds and mammals. Though these services often go unnoticed and unappreciated, they are some of the ways complex urban ecosystems help make our lives more enjoyable and comfortable.
The presence of a well-managed and diverse urban ecosystem is not always assured and, unfortunately, the impacts of an unhealthy urban ecosystem often fall disproportionately on marginalized communities. For example, in the city of Denver, it is possible to see the inequitable distribution of green space with satellite imagery. Below is an image of suburbs south of downtown Denver.
Notice the difference in greenery on either side of the South Platte River. To the right of the river, the neighborhoods are dominated by the dark green hues of abundant street trees and a large urban park dominates the center of the neighborhood. On the left side of the river, however, gray and brown hues overpower other colors, with far fewer street trees present throughout. Unsurprisingly, this divide falls largely across socio-economic lines. The greener neighborhood on the right is Washington Park, an affluent and predominantly white neighborhood. To the left however, these neighborhoods, including Ruby Hill and Athmar Park, are home to far more people of color and low income households. This socio-economic divide and the resulting ecological difference has numerous effects, including difference in the access to the health benefits of interacting with nature and on the biodiversity of these neighborhoods.15 The greener and more affluent Washington park probably hosts a greater diversity of wildlife than the neighboring communities of Ruby Hill and Athmar Park, despite their close proximity. Protecting urban ecosystems requires not just managing landscapes for wildlife and biodiversity, but addressing systemic socio-economic issues that work against such goals.
We have seen some of the ways urban landscapes provide habitat for wildlife and how they provide communities with valuable services, as well as some of the challenges that face these ecosystems. So, let us return to the images I shared at the beginning of this story and take a look at them again.
This brown field with bare trees in the background does not form the most appealing scene. Nonetheless, it provides both the ecosystem and the local community with numerous services. Snow melting here in the winter is captured by the soil, rather than flooding streets and gutters. The large cottonwood trees of the riparian woodland in the background provide habitat for owls, woodpeckers, squirrels and more. The seeds of the grasses and other plants in the foreground provide food for many different species that call this park home. The paths that meander through this park give local residents an opportunity to easily get outside and interact with nature, even in the winter when other recreational opportunities become more challenging.
Now, take a look at the second photo once more.
Though the landscape in this image is undeniably dominated by pavement and development, that doesn’t mean it serves no role in the broader ecosystem. The tall trees along the side of the street create a noise buffer between the apartments and the busy street, while providing habitat and food for birds and squirrels. Waxwings and robins feast on the crabapples and take shelter amidst the needles of the pines. Geese graze the brown grasses of the lawns below throughout the winter.
Hopefully, showing you these urban, wintry landscapes from a different perspective helps to recontextualize them and their role in the broader ecosystem. When next you find yourself outside in the winter, keep your eyes open, looking for places much like this and the creatures they shelter. Look for the bright red of crabapples or the brilliant yellow of the goldfinch. Then, when you notice those bright flashes of color in these otherwise dull landscapes, look for the less vibrant creatures that make these habitats their home too, whether it be a female house finch or a mink slinking its way along a riverbank.
As you spend more time outside in all seasons and connect with nature in your neighborhood, you might ask what you can do to increase consideration of urban greenspaces in management and urban design?
Planting native plants, especially ones whose seeds or fruits last through part or all of the winter, can help provide food and habitat for many species during the coldest months of the year. The National Audubon Society provides a curated list of recommended native plants for every zip code in the country and many local gardening clubs or nurseries may have similar information. Similarly, putting out feeding stations for birds can provide them with a reliable source of food when natural food sources are scarce. Another way to support local biodiversity is by leaving fallen leaves on the ground, where they can decompose to return nutrients to the soil and simultaneously provide shelter for many insects.
You can contribute to the protection and understanding of urban ecosystems in the wintertime on a larger scale through numerous citizen science initiatives. Submitting observations of species to projects like iNaturalist and eBird can help scientists map species distributions and track trends in populations. Beyond these global projects, there are many national or local citizen science projects that serve to collect data for various purposes, whether it be a local Christmas Bird Count or a project run by a local organization. Information collected through these projects can contribute to everything from scientific publications to policy decisions.
Though these are all valuable ways to support urban ecosystems during the winter, some issues, such as the socio-economic inequality of green space distribution and the development of healthy urban ecosystems, can’t be resolved by one person alone. Making a difference in these larger issues requires taking part in the democratic process. Voting for candidates that will advocate for further improvement of urban ecosystems and participating in grassroots organizations to make your voice heard are important ways to advocate for policy changes. Volunteering with local nonprofits, conservancies and public lands agencies can also be an effective tactic, making change at the grassroots level.
I hope you have found some appreciation for urban ecosystems in the winter as well as an understanding of the challenges facing these systems. By interacting with urban nature in the winter, we can employ solutions to support both ourselves and the rest of the organisms that share our urban landscapes during the cold, dark months of the year.
And remember, winter doesn’t last forever. Eventually, the days grow longer and the weather warmer. Trees begin to grow out new leaves and birdsong fills the air. Insects and mammals emerge from their winter hibernations.
Take care of our urban ecosystems during the winter and those efforts will bear fruit once spring arrives.
Alex Smilor is currently a student studying Ecosystem Science and Sustainability at Colorado State University. He has a passion for climate science, urban ecology, science communication, ornithology and forestry, with experience working on various research projects including collecting data for a climate adaptation study in subalpine forests and studying the effects of climate change on the population demographics of a Gentoo Penguin Colony. He currently works with the Colorado Forest Restoration Institute as a science communication intern helping develop a photo series project that aims to show how Colorado’s forests change over time as a result of forest treatments, natural disturbance, and climate change. Outside of school and work, he enjoys birdwatching, biking, camping, and playing Dungeons & Dragons.
